University of Bath, Bath BA2 7AY, United Kingdom
School of Engineering & Science, Jacobs University Bremen

Another bone of contention is that

3 content dictionaries should support both styles, since they appeal to different communities of mathematicians. We propose a new content dictionary

interprets derivatives as operators on expressions in one bound variable and presents as paradigmatic examples the following three expressions, which differ in which ways the bound variables are handled.
uplimit qualifiers that specify an ordered range of integration by allowing the bound variable to range from 0 to
condition qualifier that allows to place restrictions on the bound variable (this is possible on any binding operator), and finally example 5. uses the
domainofapplication qualifier element that restricts the bound variable to range over a set.

In this situation we propose to take the representational distinctions in examples 3. - 6. seriously model the definite integrals as distinct binding constructor as we did for differentiation. Our new
that takes two real numbers as arguments: the lower and upper limits of the range of integration, a symbol

We propose a new content dictionary
that is more closely aligned with
2 representation intuitions as a replacement for the
For differentiation and integration over expressions with bound variables we should use the
symbols, and for differentiation and integration over functions we should use
symbols. This is directly analogous to the situation between the content dictionaries

Finally, we remark that the use of binding constructors like we use them in the
content dictionary allows us to move the
condition elements into (suitably defined) binding constructors, so that the core
format need not be extended to achieve synchronization with
particular note that an analog to the new symbol
that takes an expression involving the bound variable as an argument cannot be added to
, since the bound variable in the condition cannot be accessed outside the
The only thing that has be be changed/clarified in the
3 standard is that scope of the bound variable (and thus replacement in
-renaming) extends to the binding operator. As we have to clarify alpha renaming for attributions anyway, this seems like the lesser evil in comparison with extending the
format with a condition element, in particular since existing
only uses symbols as binding operators.
This proposal has been greatly influenced by discussions with Florian Rabe in the context of the development of the OMDoc1.6 notation definitions.
